bibl.title: Letter from Joseph H. White to Wickliffe Rose, August 9, 1921

div1.p: White reports that there is no yellow fever in Peru, but that it is vital to continue mosquito controls for a year.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph H. White to Wickliffe Rose, August 9, 1921
div1.opener:
- COPY -
Gran Hotel Maury
Lima, Peru
August 9, 1921
Dear Dr. Rose:
div1.p:
I got here this A.M. and find that the ESSIQUIBO sails
this day for New York, and I am scribbling a brief note to send
on her by Hanson, who goes to Panama, but will return before
September 1.

There has been no authentic case since about July 9, and
I am more than doubtful about that one. Hanson's work has been
very, very good and against odds and opposition most annoying.

I don't think that Peru will finance the work with any-
thing but promises, and I think it really is vastly important to
hold the present status of mosquito work just where it is for a
year.

It may be done for less than Hanson has told you--and it
may not--in any event, I think it must be done.

Guayaquil must be improved; and being satisfied with Peru.
I am now going back to Ecuador and stay long enough to insure the
re-establishment of a safe minimum of breeding.
